message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bleeding from the nipple, dilated duct, and well-defined solitary mass suggest intraductal papilloma. Invasive ductal carcinoma often presents with a palpable mass and Paget disease of the breast involves the nipple and areola. Papillary carcinoma is a subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma that usually presents as a solitary mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bleeding from the nipple and the ultrasonography showing a dilated duct enclosing a well-defined solitary mass suggest the most likely diagnosis is intraductal papilloma. Invasive ductal carcinoma would show a palpable mass and also would not explain the bleeding from the nipple. Paget disease of the breast would present with scaling, crusting, and itching of the nipple. Papillary carcinoma is a type of intraductal carcinoma but is rare compared to intraductal papilloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bleeding from the nipple is most likely caused by an intraductal papilloma, which is a benign tumor that grows within the milk ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in women who are not pregnant or breastfeeding. The fact that there is no palpable mass and that the ultrasound shows a solitary mass enclosed within a dilated duct further supports this diagnosis. Invasive ductal carcinoma and papillary carcinoma are both types of breast cancer, but they typically present with a palpable mass and are not usually associated with nipple bleeding. Paget disease of the breast is a rare form of breast cancer that presents with eczematous changes around the nipple and is often associated with underlying ductal carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and family history suggest a possibility of breast cancer, but the ultrasonography results show a solitary mass enclosed by a dilated duct, which indicates intraductal papilloma. Invasive ductal carcinoma can be felt as a lump, and Paget disease of the breast usually presents with skin changes such as itching and redness. Papillary carcinoma can present as a solitary mass, but there is no evidence of bleeding from the nipple.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical finding suggested intraductal papilloma, which is a benign tumor that can cause discharge from the nipple. Invasive ductal carcinoma and Paget disease of the breast are forms of breast cancer, but with different clinical findings. Papillary carcinoma typically presents as a solitary mass with no discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has bleeding from a nipple, which suggests an issue with the mammary ducts. The presence of a dilated duct enclosing a well-defined solitary mass on ultrasound suggests intraductal papilloma, which is a benign tumor that occurs in the mammary ducts. Breast cancer is less likely given the patient's young age and the absence of a palpable mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bleeding from the nipple suggests intraductal pathology. The absence of a palpable mass and the ultrasound finding of a solitary mass enclosed within a dilated duct suggests intraductal papilloma as the most likely diagnosis. Paget disease of the breast involves the nipple and areola. Invasive ductal carcinoma and papillary carcinoma both typically present with a palpable mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an intraductal papilloma, which is a benign tumor that can cause bleeding from the nipple. The ultrasound findings also support this diagnosis. Invasive ductal carcinoma and Paget disease of the breast typically present with palpable masses and more extensive abnormal findings on imaging. Papillary carcinoma is a rare type of breast cancer and is unlikely given the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that it is a benign condition. The bleeding from the nipple may be caused by a benign tumor such as an intraductal papilloma, which can be confirmed with the ultrasonography showing a well-defined solitary mass. Invasive ductal carcinoma, Paget disease of the breast, and papillary carcinoma may present with similar symptoms but are less likely based on the presented information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms, bleeding from the nipple of the right breast for 3 months, and the ultrasonography result, which shows a dilated duct enclosing a well-defined solitary mass, the most likely diagnosis is intraductal papilloma. Invasive ductal carcinoma presents as a palpable mass, and Paget disease of the breast presents with erythema and scaling of the nipple. Papillary carcinoma is a type of breast cancer that presents with a small, solid, and well-circumscribed mass.
